docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Thomas L. Friedman is right when he argues that to win the war on terrorism, leaders of the Islamic world must step forward to counter the message of Islamic radicalism (column, Jan. 6). He is a bit more optimistic than I am abou...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Thomas L. Friedman is right when he argues that to win the war on terrorism, leaders of the Islamic world must step forward to counter the message of Islamic radicalism (column, Jan. 6). He is a bit more optimistic than I am about the possibility that the major players in the Arab world will cooperate in this effort.
docs.abstract: Letter from Doug Israel says Thomas L Friedman may be too optimistic about possibility that major players in Arab world will cooperate in war on terrorism (Jan 6 Op-Ed); says Saudi Arabia is one of most despotioc and illegitimate regimes in world

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    ''Health Aid for Poor Countries'' (editorial, Jan. 3) made persuasive arguments for increasing United States health aid to poor countries. But it didn't mention some points that have become highly relevant to the United States' s...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Health Aid for Poor Countries'' (editorial, Jan. 3) made persuasive arguments for increasing United States health aid to poor countries. But it didn't mention some points that have become highly relevant to the United States' self-interest.
docs.abstract: Phyllis Teitelbaum letter says one benefit of increasing US health-care aid to poor countries is that healthy people who see promising future for themselves and their children are much less likely to be recruited into terrorist groups (S)

docs.snippet: On Dec. 19, 1951, the Northrop Grumman Corporation, then an aircraft company, was listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Last Wednesday, Northrop's chief executive, Kent Kresa, celebrated the anniversary by ringing the closing bell of the Big Boar...
docs.lead_paragraph: On Dec. 19, 1951, the Northrop Grumman Corporation, then an aircraft company, was listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Last Wednesday, Northrop's chief executive, Kent Kresa, celebrated the anniversary by ringing the closing bell of the Big Board. Since the listing, Northrop has grown into an $18 billion military contractor whose products are used in the war in Afghanistan and whose stock has risen 20 percent since Sept. 11. In fact, Mr. Kresa noted that a dollar invested in the Dow Jones industrial average on the day Northrop was listed would be worth $37 today. That same money invested in Northrop stock would be worth $231. In Mr. Kresa's view: ''So, we've done O.K.'' Leslie Wayne
docs.abstract: Northrop Grumman Corp chief executive, Kent Kresa, notes that one dollar invested in Dow Jones industrial average on Dec 19, 1951, day Northrop was listed on New York Stock Exchange, would be worth $37 today, but that one dollar invested in Northrop stock would have grown to $231; photo (S)

byline.original: By Leslie Wayne (COMPILED BY RICK GLADSTONE)

docs.snippet: PRATT-Charles Norris, 78. Of Noank, Connecticut, passed on March 27, 2002. He was a direct descendant of William Pratt, the first settler of Essex, Connecticut. He was also the great-great-greatgrandson of the merchant John Taylor of Glasgow and N...
docs.lead_paragraph: PRATT-Charles Norris, 78. Of Noank, Connecticut, passed on March 27, 2002. He was a direct descendant of William Pratt, the first settler of Essex, Connecticut. He was also the great-great-greatgrandson of the merchant John Taylor of Glasgow and New York, one of early New York's prominent citizens. Mr. Pratt served in the navy during World War II and graduated from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in 1950. In New York he worked as an architect for Walker and Poor, J. Gordon Carr, and Edward Durell Stone. Mr. Pratt was later an architectural photographer and secretary of the Architectural Photographers Association. He was a pioneering conservationist, an accomplished sailor, a lifelong fly fisherman, and an expert at fly tying. He is survived by his wife, Priscilla, a daughter, Catherine, and a son, Timothy.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRATT, CHARLES NORRIS

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Raja Shehadeh (''The Path From Oslo to War,'' Op-Ed, April 2) blames the settlements for the breakdown of the Oslo peace process and for the current wave of violence. Israeli settlements are not now the issue; Palestinian terrori...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Raja Shehadeh (''The Path From Oslo to War,'' Op-Ed, April 2) blames the settlements for the breakdown of the Oslo peace process and for the current wave of violence. Israeli settlements are not now the issue; Palestinian terrorism is. Settlements were on the table at Camp David and Yasir Arafat rejected it then. They will not again be on the table until peace talks resume. President Bush had it exactly right on Saturday when he said, ''All the leaders in the world must stand up against terror,'' and pointedly added, ''And that especially applies to Chairman Arafat.''
docs.abstract: Letter by American Jewish Congress director Neil B Goldstein says Mideast issue is not Israeli settlements but Palestinian terrorism, just as Pres Bush has said

headline.main: In the Mideast, A Widening Divide

docs.snippet: MYERS-Willis F. ''Jim'', 85. Died on January 17, 2002. Interment was private. He leaves his sister, Grace Myers Sachtleben, his niece Nancy Sachtleben Mitchell, both of Denver, CO and his nephew Alan Sachtleben of North Chatham, MA. Mr. Myers was ...
docs.lead_paragraph: MYERS-Willis F. ''Jim'', 85. Died on January 17, 2002. Interment was private. He leaves his sister, Grace Myers Sachtleben, his niece Nancy Sachtleben Mitchell, both of Denver, CO and his nephew Alan Sachtleben of North Chatham, MA. Mr. Myers was a lifelong resident of the north New Jersey area and for many years maintained a summer home in Kennebunkport, ME. He was a graduate of Rutgers University and was a captain in the U S Army during World War II. In 1947 he joined the music rights organization, SESAC Inc., and remained with that organization until his retirement in 1991. He was one of the founding fathers of the Gospel Music Association (GMA) in Nashville, TN and in 1993 was inducted into that organization's Gospel Music Hall of Fame. Memorial donations may be made to the South Congregational Church, P. O. Box 414, Kennebunkport, ME. 04046.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Memorials  MYERS, WILLIS F. ''JIM''

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    A dysfunctional English department at Columbia (''Columbia Soothes the Dogs of War in Its English Dept.,'' front page, March 17), like the recent flap over African-American studies at Harvard, makes for juicy reading -- the very ...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A dysfunctional English department at Columbia (''Columbia Soothes the Dogs of War in Its English Dept.,'' front page, March 17), like the recent flap over African-American studies at Harvard, makes for juicy reading -- the very stuff that might find its way into a mystery by Amanda Cross (a k a the ex-Columbia English professor Carolyn Heilbrun)!
docs.abstract: Prof John Jeffries Martin letter says dysfunctional college departments make juicy reading, cries shame on colleagues at Columbia and Harvard for holding onto privileged posts, failing to retire by 70 and keeping other positions unoccupied (S)

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    ''Children as Barter in a Famished Land'' (front page, March 8) recounted the unspeakable misery of Afghan boys sold by their starving families -- a tragedy of poverty and war. But the article barely mentions girl-selling, only o...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Children as Barter in a Famished Land'' (front page, March 8) recounted the unspeakable misery of Afghan boys sold by their starving families -- a tragedy of poverty and war. But the article barely mentions girl-selling, only observing the practice of selling young girls into marriage.
docs.abstract: Natl Orgn for Women pres Kim Gandy letter on March 9 article recounting unspeakable misery of Afghan boys sold by their starving parents; points out that article barely mentions girl-selling, which translates into forced labor and sexual slavery

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Margaret Thatcher (''Advice to a Superpower,'' Op-Ed, Feb. 11) is wrong when she suggests that we should not concern ourselves with the rebuilding of Afghanistan. After World War II, America spent untold millions rebuilding Europ...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Margaret Thatcher (''Advice to a Superpower,'' Op-Ed, Feb. 11) is wrong when she suggests that we should not concern ourselves with the rebuilding of Afghanistan. After World War II, America spent untold millions rebuilding Europe and Japan, and it proved to be money well spent. The Sept. 11 attacks were awful to endure, but they did not change as much as is often suggested, and as Lady Thatcher suggests again. For a world that endured the threat of Nazi Germany and its allies, this most recent threat reminds us that the world is a dangerous place. That is nothing new.
docs.abstract: Letter from Bruce Neuman says Margaret Thatcher, in her Feb 11 Op-Ed on American response to terrorism, is wrong to suggest that US should not concern itself with rebuilding of Afghanistan

headline.main: America's Task In a Perilous World
